title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. Insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits. To be insured for an RRB annuity, a worker must generally have at least 10 years of covered railroad work. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) provides annuities to insured railroad workers based on their covered railroad work. The annuities are equivalent to or greater than Social Security benefits. There are two components: tier I, similar to Social Security benefits, and tier II, paid in addition to tier I. Tier I amounts increase annually with a cost-of-living adjustment. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) provides tier II retirement amounts in addition to tier I amounts, based solely on covered railroad service. Tier II amounts are increased annually by 32.5% of the Social Security COLA. Surviving spouses of railroad workers may be eligible for widow or widower annuities from RRB, which are generally higher than comparable Social Security benefits. At full retirement age, a surviving spouse may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity. The Railroad Retirement Board provides tier II retirement amounts in addition to tier I amounts, based on covered railroad service. Surviving spouses may be eligible for up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity. Widows and widowers may receive a reduced annuity as early as age 60. Additionally, widows caring for a deceased worker's child under age 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100% of the worker's tier II amount. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widows and widowers. The Railroad Retirement Board made changes to widow(er)'s annuities in 2001, including investing funds in non-governmental assets, removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience, reducing vesting years for tier II annuities, repealing a maximum limitation on annuities, and phasing in changes to the tier II tax structure. These changes apply to widow(er)s receiving annuities starting in February 2002 or later, with some exceptions for those who began receiving annuities before that date. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s by adding a new guaranty amount. Widow(er)s now receive 100% of the employee's tier I amount and 50% of the tier II amount, with an additional supplemental guaranty amount. The total initial minimum amount under current law is 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts, minus any applicable reductions. Both tier I and regular tier II amounts increase annually for widow(er)s. The widow(er)'s annuity remains constant in nominal terms but decreases in real terms over time due to adjustments for inflation. The guaranty amount offsets the COLA increase, keeping the total annuity unchanged until the guaranty amount is reduced to zero. After that, the total monthly annuity increases as tier I and regular tier II amounts continue to rise annually. The widow(er) receives an increase in monthly annuity for the first time, with annuities under current law exceeding those under prior law. Average aged widow(er) annuity increased from $1,138 to $1,416 in real 2005 dollars after changes in 2001. An illustration shows how widow(er) annuities are calculated under current and prior law. The widow's initial annuity under prior law in 2006 would have been $1,150, while under current law it would be $1,300 per month. Her total annuity amount is $150 more than under prior law due to the addition of a guaranty amount. The widow's total annuity would not increase between 2006 and 2012 until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed her initial minimum amount. The widow's total annuity amount would not increase between 2006 and 2012, even though her tier I and regular tier II amounts would change each year. In 2007, her tier I amount would increase by $23 and her regular tier II amount by $1. Despite not receiving a COLA, her total tier II annuity under current law would be $277 in 2007, which is greater than what she would have received under prior law. In 2012, the widow's total monthly annuity would start to increase due to COLAs, with her guaranty amount gradually decreasing to zero. Her total monthly annuity under current law would be $1,323 in 2012, higher than the previous year. This amount would remain the same in 2012 and subsequent years, matching what it would have been under prior law. Under prior law, the widow's monthly annuity in 2006 would have been $1,150, consisting of tier I and tier II amounts. However, under current law, the widow's total annuity in 2006 would be $1,300, including the guaranty amount. The guaranty amount decreases each year after 2006 as tier I and tier II amounts increase.
